Dear Harrison 5 Thank you for your letter of the 10th of February about air mail services between Koweit and Iraq. We will await your agreement before writing to the Iraq Portal Administration as proposed in ray letter of the 31st of January. • On the further points which you raise I should perhaps explain that responsibility for the routing of mails in the international postal service rests with the Administrations of origin who, under standing international arrangements,can make use for this purpose of any land, sea or air services provided by other postal administrations and are responsible for meeting all conveyance charges. In the case of air mails from the U.K, for Koweit, conveyance as far as Basra is provided by a British air service, viz. B.O.A.C., and we arranged with the Iraq postal administration for the mails to be sent on from Basra by Iraqi Airways (a service provided by Iraq) as soon as we learned that the service was available to us. In actual practice, we at present enclose our air mail correspondence for Koweit in separate bundles in the air mails for Basra with a suit- ble advice of the weight, and these advices form the basis of the claims made upon us by the Iraq post office for the onward conveyance from Basra, but we are now considering making up closed mails addressed directly to Koweit. We have not seen a copy of any reply from Ratcliffe Cousins and I presume that no decision has so far been taken on the question of making Koweit a call on the '.O.A.C. air services, but in any event we must now make plans for the disposal of air mail correspondence from Koweit after the 1st of April- when we are due to take over responsibility from the Indian Post Office. In pursuance of our general policy in regard to air mail services we should wish to make the best use of such air services as are available, and while we prefer to use British air services if at' all possible, we should, in the absence of a suitable British air service, have no hesitation in using a foreign one. Indeed air mails from the United Kingdom for Koweit are already carried on the Iraqi Airways service from Basra. Normally, air services which convey mails operate for the purpose as agents of a particular postal adminisoracion ^usually the postal administration of the country to which the air service belongs) which collects the appropriate mail conveyance charges /from E.P.Donaldson, Esq.from other administrations whose mails are carried* These conveyance charges are notified by the responsible postal administration to other Administrations through the medium of the International Bureau of the Universal Postal Union and are expressed in gold francs per kilogramme* The postal administration of Iraq has notified in this way the availability of the Iraqi Airways service for the conveyance of other administrations' mails from Iraq to Koweit at the conveyance rate of 3 gold francs per kilogramme which, however, cove/s conveyance over the sector Baghdad - Koweit, and we assume, although this has yet to be confirmed, that the service in the reverse direction is similarly under the control of the Iraq Postal administration. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file. There are notes at the beginning of the file, on folio 2. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file; they give brief description of the correspondence with a reference number, which refers back to that correspondence in the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 20; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file concerns arrangements for the delivery of airmail between UK and Kuwait, and between Kuwait and Iraq.The file contains correspondence between the UK General Post Office, the Commonwealth Relations Office, the India Office, and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf.
